description: Measures the ability to break water's 'skin.' In cold water, surface tension is naturally higher; the detergent must lower this to allow the liquid to penetrate fabric pores.
The tension between wash water and oily soil. In cold water, oils are often solid; achieving ultra-low IFT is required to 'roll up' grease without heat.
The concentration where surfactants form micelles. A low CMC in cold water ensures cleaning efficiency even at lower product dosages.
The speed molecules travel to the stain. Since cold water slows movement, slow kinetics can cause the wash cycle to end before the detergent reaches the dirt.
Measures tension during the first few milliseconds of agitation. Critical for short cold-wash cycles where equilibrium is never reached.
The 'freeze point' for surfactant activity. Below this temperature, the detergent remains as inactive crystals providing zero cleaning.
The temperature where non-ionics become insoluble. For cold water, you must ensure this point is not reached during product storage or transport.
Indicates if a molecule prefers oil or water. An HLB of 12–15 is typically required to ensure surfactants stay dissolved in cold water.
The temp where an emulsion flips phases. Prevents the detergent from 'locking' onto clothes as a greasy residue in cold environments.
The electrical charge on soil particles. A high negative charge ensures dirt and fabric repel each other, preventing 'graying' of clothes.
Strength of the water softener. In cold water, builders must bind minerals faster than the minerals can deactivate the surfactants.
Measures how well a surfactant keeps oil suspended. High values prevent oil from settling back onto fabric during the rinse.
The ability of the formula to keep solid dirt (clay/soot) from clumping together in the cold wash liquor.
The speed of the enzyme. Cold water requires 'psychrophilic' enzymes that maintain a high catalytic rate at 15°C.
Measures enzyme affinity for a stain. A low Km means the enzyme is highly effective even at low stain concentrations.
Bottle stability. Cold-water enzymes are fragile and need stabilization to prevent degradation by other formula components.
The environmental footprint. High biodegradability is a key requirement for biosurfactants like rhamnolipids.
Defines pourability. In cold weather, detergents can thicken; viscosity must be extracted across a temperature range to ensure usability.
Speed of solubility. In cold HE washes, if dissolution takes >45 seconds, it can leave white residues on clothing.
The lowest temperature at which the liquid flows. Crucial for products stored in unheated environments.
Measures sudsing. Excess foam in a cold wash can cause 'sudslock' in HE machines, stopping mechanical cleaning action.
